remixed_from.title: Kinect slider with 3030 aluminum profile for 3D Scanning

description.text:
Update 07.05.2017
Sorry, i forgot the Joystick Case.
Now available!

Here is my remix of the Kinect Bodyscanner.
All parts I have printed from PLA with 50% filling.

Hardware:
1x Nema 17 Stepper
5x 608 ball bearing
1x Arduino Uno
1x A3967 EasyDriver
1x GT2 toothed belt
1x GT2 Pulley
2x LM393 Speed Sensor or Reipolished Collision Switch
1x JoyStick Breakout Modul PS2

1x 2m 3030 aluminum profile
4x 40cm 3030 aluminum profile
4x 3030 angle
5x 3030 end caps (but you can also find here on Thingiverse)
Various metric screws.

The Arduino Sketch is once designed for the LM393 Speed Sensor and once for the three-pole collision switch (as seen in the shears).
By pressing the stick different speeds can be set.
In the sketch you can change various steps (half steps, whole step etc.)

My version has got an update.
A switch for manual and automatic operation.
One switch for the light and the turntable.

As soon as I have finished my turntable, I will adjust the Arduino Sketch.

Hier ist mein Remix des Kinect Bodyscanners.
Alle Teile habe ich aus PLA mit 50% Füllung gedruckt.

Hardware:

4x 3030 Winkel
5x 3030 Endkappen (findet man aber auch hier auf Thingiverse)
Diverse Metrische Schrauben.

Der Arduino Sketch ist einmal für den LM393 Speed Sensor designed und einmal für den einen dreipoligen Kollision Switch (wie in der Shematik zu sehen).
Durch drücken des Sticks können verschieden Geschwindigkeiten eingestellt werden.
Im Sketch können diverse Schritte verändert werden (Halbe Schritte, Ganze Schritt etc.)

Meine Version hat noch ein Update bekommen.
Ein Schalter für Manuell und Automatik betrieb.
Jeweils ein Schalter für Licht und den Drehteller.

Sobald ich meinen Drehteller fertig habe, werde ich den Arduino Sketch anpassen.

description.text:
This is a remix from great design of Nikolay Grigoryev :) I liked his design very much, i've made one for science fest here in Krasnoyarsk, and it did great :)

The changes i made are:

  • The knobs are designed to use metric M6 bolts and nuts
  • The use of dc geared motors is supposed (like JGB37) (and so the holders are added)
  • The holder for web-camera is added
  • The holders for HC-SR04 ultrasonic distance sensors are added

This bot was controlled by Raspberry Pi 3 with Arduino Uno onboard, a motor driver was used to drive the robot.

remixed_from.title: Customizable direct drive extruder for E3D v6 hotend for Prusa i3 / Wilson / Geeetech

title: Carriage updated + Extruder support (E3D v6 MK8 direct extruder) for Milled/Printed 3D Printer. v1.0

description.text:
E3D V6 EXTRUDER + MK8 for Milled/Printed 3D Printer.

Features:

  • You can now fasten the belt without using plastic tabs.
  • The weight of the engine was centered on the top of the trolley, eliminating instability.
  • Easy use of MK8 E3D extruder with direct injection.

Bearing 624ZZ / RIGHT SIDE IN USE.

Based in 2 projects:
Printer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1524754
Extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383913

Other parts used in the extruder, How which screws were used, consult the original link: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383913

PS (ATENTION):

  • You can glue the extruder holder with epoxy plastic solder in the car, or just screw it, I recommend gluing, but before doing this, before placing the bearings and outside the printer you should glue and let dry for 24 hours . Only after complete curing of the glue, place the LM8UU bearings and install the carriage and soon after you should put the top screw to center the extruder holder in the car, but do not tighten, just place to center! Then you must put the 4 screws of the extruder holder in the front and tighten it so that it is firmly fixed. Then install the bolts that will secure the linear bearings (LM8uu), press lightly and stop when you start to feel some pressure! Very light! Only then tighten the upper screw to the same degree as the bearing bolts! Very calm!

  • Do not over tighten the bolts, the locking mechanism itself secures the bearings. The space for the screws was made to compensate for spaces that are caused by time

This is a Feeder Back-plate for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus so that flexible filament can be printed without the filament escaping through any gaps.

There are two versions,
the first is suitable to use with the stock nozzle setup,
the second is suitable for use with the Swiss Micro hot end Mod, it has a counter bore on the bottom surface to take the top protuberance of the Swiss Micro assembly.

The modified plate has a small web that aligns with the pressure bearing groove preventing the flexible filament escaping via this small gap.

I would recommend printing at 0.1mm layer height with it lying on what is the right end surface as you look at the print head, print with supports, in the material of choice, this area didn't get hot in testing with a plate printed in TwoBears PLAtech.

During assembly align the small curved web with the groove in the pressure bearing.

This is a 'What Duck' design

comments.text:
The bottom hole is approx 3.1mm on both versions with the Swiss micro version having an additional counterbore for the Swiss micro part that extendes slightly above the hotend. This is so there is no added friction from the sides and the hole is shallow between the feeder and the hot-end.
This modified plate makes it easier to print with flexible filaments that tend to find ways of exiting the feeder/hotend where they can but is fine to leave in place to print with other filaments.
comments.author: SidHiscocks

comments.text:
Just printed this and have a question.
Is the filament hole supposed to be about 3mm wide?
comments.author: Wol_Gran

comments.text:
No print it with the back of the main plate on the print bed, the side that goes against the feeder motor.
In the main photo you are looking down on the top of the print along the axis of the motor.

I wanted to add Vibration dampening feet to my Replicator 1. I looked for some that would fit but they had been taken down so i created these as a remix from the Replicator 2 Vibration feet by fa-weberad and i added feet that fit the Replicator 1 by  etrohn  
To make it work really well i added a dab of hot glue on each joint as well as the bottom so it would stick.

The spring parts may need a little bit of sanding to fit in the slot. Adding a bit of hot glue to each connection make sure they do not wiggle loose. Also adding hot glue to the bottom and then smooth it will act as a grip so the plastic does not slide around. Print 2 of the left and 2 for the right
or
print 2 of the plated replicator_1_vibration_feet.stl

title: Prusa MK2 filament guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a simple filement guide which I designed for my Prusa. It is super simple to juse. Just use hexagon hole on the Prusa z rod mount to attach small part, and slide bigger one on the frame center. You will also need 35cm of ptfe tube. To have complete system you will also need spool holder (I use this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1806139 )

There is NO negative effect on print quality. If you push your ptfe all way into the hole, there is very little additional drag (just make sure filament is not grinding any edges). If you compare it to stock prusa spool holder, it is even easier to pull filament from the spool. As a proof photo of green benchy :)

I keep this one as in progress, because I want feedback regarding tolerances. Everything is tight fit and works great on my side, but want other people to comment.

If you made it, please share photo. It is always nice to see one :)

edit 14.05.2017:

  • Frame center.stl replaced with Frame center_large.stl. Geometry is almost the same - I added one radius at the end of tube, to make sure filament is not touching it even at extreme extruding positions
  • Added Frame center_small.stl. It is 20mm shorter. It comes in handy when you have paver tile in your enclosure - then with shorter arm tube is not touching the enclosure.

edit 28.02.2017:

  • Modified both shorter and longer center fram element to make it fit frame tighter. Now it is 6mm wide instead previous 6.4mm

Prusa

No

Notes:

If you want to use it in enclosure, print it in PET or ABS.
It takes like 2.5 hour to print using standard Prusa 0.3mm profile.

comments.text: Noticed today that the side piece appears to block the Right Z-axis from completely topping out as the piece extends down ~2mm below the Z guide and hits the screws of the trapezoid nuts. This may affect calibration as it aligns the X-axis via the vertical Z-axis rods topping both sides out identically. This might get leveled out by the built in calibration of the i3 but it still adds a bit of screw that could be engineered out of it.
comments.author: MadWeezel

comments.text: Good observation. This is possible. Unfortunately I do not have possibility to correct it, as I do not own Prusa any longer. My recommendation would be to just take it off when calibrating.

description.header: Problem: pot-rack hooks are easy to dislodge
description.text: Pot racks are a great way to maximize storage space in the kitchen. However, the hooks typically fit quite loosely over the rack. As a result, it can be hard to get a pot on and off the rack without knocking the hook off.

This thing fits snugly between the pot rack and the hook. They help hold the hook in place so that it's much easier to get pots on and off. These stabilizers are designed for the "Range Kleen Oval Pot Rack", available from Amazon.

Just print as many as you need. They are not particularly hard to print. They don't have a lot of surface area in contact with the bed, so you might have adhesion problems if your printer isn't set up just so.

This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2137716 mount.

It has a hole for the power button and also slots for battery straps.

Printer:

Folgertech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15

remixed_from.author: Robert256
remixed_from.title: Hose connector for standard household faucet

title: Gardena connector for standard household faucet

description.text:
This thing makes it possible to plug a generic Gardena connector to your faucet.
I needed to be able to plug a hose to my faucet and saw the 'hose connector to household faucet'-thing so I cut the hose connector part out and added a Gardena connector.

Just unscrew the faucet cap and remove the filter, put this thing where the filter were and screw it back together.

I've tried it on my faucet from IKEA (Sundsvik) and it works as expected, I think it will work just fine on most faucets.

--update
v2 - the first design I got to work, but it had a pretty small hole diameter at the faucet end
v3 - made the hole just as big at the faucet end as the Gardena end, this increased the flow
v4 - updated it to have a slightly bigger hole diameter at the faucet end, which led to less leakage
v5 - Updated the design to make it stronger, it had a weak spot where it constantly broke and now I've made it thicker.

Printer:

Craftbot Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 microns

Infill:

75%

Notes:

Printed with ABS
On the best working print I used 4 loops + perim.
Almost no leakage on that one.
Some sanding was required to make it fit properly.
I used Meshmixer to cut out the parts i needed. 123D design to add them together.

description.text:
A variety of socket organizers that I printed to add some organization to my toolbox.

I printed two organizers for my 3/8" (9mm) drives (one for metric, one for SAE) and one for my 1/4" (6mm) drive sockets (both SAE and Metric).

The Spacing is quite high to allow for a variety of different sized sockets to fit. I recommend using the "Metric Socket Holder - 9mm" as it has a thinner base (thus saving unnecessary material).

The last "Long Socket Holder" was for my leftover long sockets that had diameters of about 12-14 mm.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm layer height

Infill:

5-10

Notes:

Printed with both Village Plastics ABS and Polylite PLA.

For ABS, make sure you have a heated bed (I had mine at 110 C)

I used glue stick to hold down the abs from warping.

NOTE The STL Files are oriented incorrectly. Be sure to lay the flat side on the print surface.

I made these using Solidworks. First made a base plate and then extruded 6mm and/or 9mm pegs from the base and added a chamfer to the top.

Very simple to recreate. Feel free to use the uploaded designs to edit for your use.

comments.text:
Hi Penguin3634,
I made a snow pea too and I also use Tinkercad, so I can try telling you a few tips I use for myself. (Please forgive me if all I'm doing is criticizing... :) The first thing I always make sure of is to keep the practicality of the model (how it will actually print) first, how it looks is only secondary. That's why I always make my plants with thick stems and leaves, and the zombies with thicker arms. The stem on your snow pea seems thin, making it easier to crack when printed. Another big point is making sure the model will stand on it's own after being printed. That includes making sure the bottom surface is relatively wide, and lays flat on the surface (the back bottom leaf on your model is sticking up off the surface, and that'll probably make it fall backwards.), and making sure you have an equal balance on both sides. Another point is making sure all parts of the model are entirely attached. The ring on the end of snow pea's mouth looks like it might be a little detached (the same thing happened to me with the ring at the end of my fume-shroom model), and won't print entirely connected. I always nudge those type of parts slightly more into the surface of the model. Also, it's good to try to pay attention to detail. For example, your snow pea has no eyes, and although you can paint it afterwards, having two small indents in the head makes it much easier for that. And don't take my word for it, but I think there's a little too many ice crystals in the back of his head, and they stick out too much. So I hope this helped you. (sorry again for too much criticism:)
Good luck!

description.text:
Reuleaux triangle
This week Angus on Makers Muse (1) presented a really interesting shape, that roles like a sphere but was a triangle, cool eh. This really messes with convention, so much so, you really need to try it for yourself.

We form the Reuleaux triangle by using three intersecting circular disks, each having their centre on the boundary of the other two(2). This produces a curve of constant width, normal we would think this should be a circle, but in this case its a triangle(3)!!! So, what can you do with this constant width triangle, well you can roll them between two flat surfaces like they were ball bearings... Take a look at Angus' link below, and have a go for yourself:-)

I would suggest printing at least three.

Definition of constant width is when two lines have the same Euclidean distance from each other.

Reference:-

  1. MakersMuse YouTube - https://youtu.be/2eUWT9cI23o
  2. Wikipedia - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuleaux_triangle
  3. Leonhard Euler - 1781- Paper on De curvis triangularibus.

I used Grey PLA from https://rigid.ink but you can use any colour you wish:-)

Vector 3D Printer

No

Yes

20% to reduce print time

Notes:

Notes adheres to : Buildtak bed https://www.buildtak.eu

You will need supports to create this shape

You will need supports to make this shape, I used Simply3De default options here, but you will need a pair of pliers to remove, you will then need to tidy with a file... I'll post some images of this tomorrow.

I used Autodesk Fusion 360 to design this thing, and Simplify3D, using default support settings to print this on my Vector 3D Printer.

I tried one of the existing SGS8 models and changed the Dims to that of an SGS8+ (159.5 x 73.4 x 8.1 mm (6.28 x 2.89 x 0.32 in)). That did not work properly. I created a block (in AutoDesk 123D Design) to the S8+ Dims, then started to Chamfer and Fillet the edges and corners, by eye, to this shape. I have been printing with ABS, so I will need to figure out the appropriate upsample percentage, to account for shrinkage due to cooling. This is a work in progress, to make an analog 8+, so I can use it to create negative space in docks for my phone. I still need to account for/add buttons, cam, finger print sensor, LED and targets for the speaker, USB-C, 3.5mm jack, and whatever the hole is on the top.

title: Micro Quad fpv Racer 100mm  Brushless 0703 1S 20.000kv
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here is a mini racer 100mm made of polycarbonate equipped with brushless 0703 1S version 20.000kv.

This mini quad is very fast for 1S and very resistant (thanks to the polycarbonate).

This frame has been designed to protect the entire brushless which are very fragile in 0703 without harming the cooling thanks to the passage of air in the frame

There are two chassis versions, a soft Mount TPU 1mm version that greatly reduces vibration and distortion in the brushless.

With brushless it is full power! Especially from 12.000 kv to 20.000kv.

Fullly equipped (camera 600tvl 25mW, micro buzzer and micro led)

Fasteners: 4X M1.6 in 20mm + mini shrinkable sleeve to avoid circuit courts

To avoid vibrations, please use the soft mounts made with TPU and designed to

Let the air pass and cool the engine otherwise you could also damage the motors.

title: 696 mini fidget spinner 6x15x5mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had some left over 696 bearings from printing a copy of thing:2194520 and figured why not make them into a small spinner!
So I made my first design in Fusion 360 and this is the end result and I'm very pleased!

Cap's and bearing's fit perfect, might need to tap the bearings in to fully seat, but they should be flush on both top and bottom.
The caps fit great by hand and don't rub. There's 2 sizes, the smaller is 12mm to let you see the bearings underneath just a bit, and the larger one is 15mm (the same size as the bearing itself) so it gives a nice clean look, and as small as these are, a little more room to grab.

And of course I had to make a few versions with different numbers and designs, and we all wanted to see how many would fit, so of course I had to release the 7 lobed version as well :D

Hope you enjoy!

amazon link to 696 bearing's I used: http://a.co/boVcWu2

edit - last few pic's were just to show size comparison between these and standard 608 bearing spinners

edit 05/08/17 - Added thicker versions of the cap's for those having loose fit's.

Printer:

Anet A2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

50-70%

Notes:

I've printed in both 0.2 and 0.1 just for testing and both came out just fine, the fillet is a bit more noticeable on 0.1 obviously but both have soft, not sharp, edges off the platter so that's really all I wanted.

I printed this in black PETG by eSUN.
2 walls, 0.4 nozzle, 50mm/s print speed, 25mm/s outside perimeters, 70% "lines" infill sliced in cura 2.04 (still having first/second layer issues in 2.05) and they come out great!

Fast too! at 0.2 they take less than half an hour, and less than an hour at 0.1. Sweet!

print_settings.Notes:: NOTE

title: Salvaged Boombox Rex Portable Bluetooth Speaker

description.text:
My mom had this "Boombox Rex" bluetooth speaker that broke. It turned out that connections on the inside had been disconnected, but unfortunately, I broke the enclosure when I opened it.

Thank goodness we have 3D printing! I decided to improve the sound quality by adding a 3 inch mid-range speaker, and gave it a new enclosure.

Electronics added to this design:

3 inch mid-range speaker
mini-usb breakout board (Adafruit makes good ones)
Extra wire and solder.

I basically rewired the device to add the second speaker and breakout board. If you are really curious, feel free to comment on this and I will explain in more detail. It was fairly easy to do (maybe 1.5 hours with little electronics experience).

After that I made an enclosure for the two speakers, the passive radiator that was in the original design, the button pad, and a usb port for charging the li-ion batteries inside.

I added the solidworks files as well so that you can edit it if you like.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm layer height

Infill:

15

Notes:

I used PLA for the front and nylon for the back.

NOTE - I highly advise against using nylon for this design as it is flexible and actually resonates sometimes during bass notes. Stick with a more rigid material like PLA or even ABS should work (although PLA will be way easier to print with).

I simply used plastic epoxy to glue the speakers, radiator, button pad, and usb breakout into place. Then I applied some silicone caulking to the cracks to make sure it was sealed.

Four screw holes are located on the prints to screw the two together (I would recommend some glue as well in order to properly seal it.

Lastly, I used some black silicone caulk to seal the hexagon speaker from the front and make it look nicer.

BEAM is a 3D typeface designed to be downloaded and created in which ever way the user sees fit. With technology such as 3D printing and CAM the application of BEAM is endless.
The letter forms can be edited to the users liking, they can be scaled and skewed with in most 3D printing software. Using different materials and colours Beam can be customised to the desired users preference.
BEAM can be printed in a variety of different materials. PLA and ABS may be the most common 3D printing filaments but explore using Flexi-PLA or Trans-PLA to obtain a variety of results.
Please be sure to share your results with me. I would like to see what the possibilities of the typeface are and the variety of results which can be obtained.

letters at 100% scale are 80mm tall but I encourage you to scale both up and down to your liking.

https://www.behance.net/gallery/52264159/BEAM-3D-Printed-Typeface

comments.text: Do you solder the JST connector to the board or take a "press fit" approach?
comments.author: Iconic

comments.text: Its as you says a "press fit" approach. The JSTconnector its solder to a small pieces of wire taken from an old ethernet wire and then holes in the case are enough to keep the nomemcu pins and wire together.
comments.author: Iconic

comments.text: So you soldered the ethernet wire to a JSTconnector insert that you then insert into the printed hole? Or do you skip the metal female JSTconnector and just poke the ethernet wire into the hole and then press the NodeMCU unit into the base and thus "pin down" the wires?
comments.author: virtualdrug

comments.text:
I solder the ethernet wire to the JST female. And the the other side to the case small holes. I used the ethernet wire because they have a solid core.
Then just press the nodemcu in the holes, no more soldering needed. I will upload a new picture with the details later.

description.text: Now that I have a dual extruder Ultimaker, I revisited my first model uploaded on Thingiverse.

I have no idea how people print dual extrusion with other software. But use the _a and _b stl file as you normally would.
I'm working on the software for the Ultimaker, as you can see on the photo, there is a "minor" oozing issue to solve. The print also de-attached it self from the bed before it was finished, and the 2nd color didn't come out at the start.
I printed it to see if my heads where on the same level, which they are. So I'm very happy about this print.

comments.text: Awesome work! I can't wait to get dual extrusion for my own Ultimaker one day. I'm guessing Cura will support it, since you created Cura?
comments.author: BillDem3D

comments.text: Basic dual extrusion support was added in Cura quite a while ago. This was actually my first test with it. The software support has improved a bit, and the 12.12 release will improve it a bit more. But it's still difficult as even the V2 hotend (this was done with the V1) still oozes quite a bit.
comments.author: BillDem3D

comments.text: FYI: To slice using Axon, the BFB software, a combined .STL is required. All three files, (first colour.STL, second colour.STL and combined.STL) have to be loaded.
comments.author: Glitch3DModels

comments.text: That's odd, I can understand why software would want a combined file, for things like support. But I do not understand why it cannot generate it itself. Anyhow, it should be easy to make the combined from the SCAD script.

title: Customizable Key USB Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I had one of these metal key USB's that I used to print on my Makerbot. But it was white and boring so I was thinking of how I could make it look nicer, and also more appropriate to a Makerbot. So I designed this USB cover in Fusion 360. It is printed in two pieces and glued to the USB. For the Makerbot logo, it is printed separately and again glued to the covers. It can most likely be dual extruded however I don't have a dual extruder machine to try it. I also left a blank one in case you want to customise it. If the tolerances are too tight, I might release the Fusion 360 files so they can be edited. However if your printer is well calibrated, it will work really well, in fact the logos will be slightly loose. Note: All parts are held on with super glue.

title: Tevo Power Supply Brackets with Fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Rear bracket remixed from boompy's great rear bracket design. His one half covered the new power supply's integrated fan so decided to make this one with a nice tarantula on it. The tarantula was shamelessly taken from this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1668183

I printed at 0.3 and it still took 6 hours, simplify3d lied and told me 4.5 hours. Support material took about 15 minutes to get out. Little tip if you make one, hold the spiders body when cleaning up the support. I managed to break the body along a layer line but thankfully it's unnoticeable. You will need a small file to get in between the legs where the supports were welded on.

EDIT:
I've added a front bracket that I resized from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152987
I was about to chop the rear out of the original boopy design but noticed someone had already remixed it but in a smaller size. Resized to fit the latest 2017 power supply with fan.

The front bracket I printed at 0.2mm and it turned out a lot better. Now redoing the rear one at 0.2mm, I'll update the pics when it's done.

UPDATE:
I've added the 0.2mm pics, it came out a lot nicer. Supports came off easier and it was all around a nicer print. Also added a comparison pic of 0.3mm on the left and 0.2mm on the right. Print at 0.2.

I changed the infill down to 40% and it's still rock solid. I could probably get away with less.

The 0.2mm print took 8.5 hours at 50mm/s, acceleration 1000, jerk 7.

UPDATE 2:
I've added the spider so you can print a different colour and glue it on top, see the photo.

Tevo Tarantula

title: Modular Box Organiser System for Resistors etc

description.text:
Hello All,

This is a modular box storage organizer I am working on currently.

Current size is good for resistors, capacitors, and other electronic bits.

In time/if requested the number of box sizes will grow and everything will be backwards compatible, and also allowing for bigger things to be stored in (probably next size will be something for my arduino storage box).

Should a bigger box be required is no problem as long as it's outside dimensions are multiples this first box. (tho still needs to be drawn first).

The shelves (box blanks) have a 0.6mm clearance, however based on your settings you might need to scale it up/down a bit. In my example, I actually printed them out at 99.76% scale to get a nice smooth fit.

Wall mount is done using a countersunk screw in the back of of 1 plate (see section picture).
Box outers will snap into each other,maybe use a rubber mallet. Reason is that I wanted them to lock in so that if I wall mount them, I don't need to use a screw for each box. Therefore I left 0 clearance between the boxes.

title: LED String Mount for Monoprice 13860 / Wanahao i3

description.text:
This is 2 designs for LED supports to mount on the Z axis frame for a Monoprice 13860 / Wanahao i3.

I bought some 5V LED lights from Amazon and wanted to mount them around the Z axis frame so I can more easily see the print. The LED's are in a string, roughly 36 inches long with a Velcro backing, the mating Velcro strip with adhesive backing is included. The string is terminated with a male USB connector for power (docs say 1.0 A). The link to the LED string is below.

The supports are roughly 3-1/2" long; you make 3 per side and clip them along the Z axis frame.

The first design (shown in the application pics) clips along the edge placing the LED's toward the front of the printer. The top of the LED's are flush with the edge of the frame.

The StraightSupport2_1.STL file includes a couple of updates. The first update is to narrow the ledge the LED's sit on so the LED's can be mounted on the opposite side of the Z axis frame. If the original design (not included) was mounted on the back face of the Z axis frame it would crash with the X axis trolley. So I narrowed it by 1mm - it will be snug but should clear . I also moved the LED away from the inside edge of the frame so you don't catch as much direct light from the LED's.

The second design (includes MK3 for Mark 3 in the name) includes a lip on the front edge of the LED ledge and includes the 'LED farther away from the Z axis frame edge'. Note this design includes the entire width of the original LED ledge so you won't be able to back mount (LED's to Z axis screw side) the LED's. The lip provides a bit of a cowling so you're not staring directly at the side of the LED's.

Both designs are intended to be a simple clip design. They will not fill in the top corners of the Z axis as the thickness of the corner is two plate thicknesses and I didn't include that in the design - works well enough without it.

I had a view issues printing these parts - the replacement printer to the original (burned out the heated bed controller) has been a beast. I did a 3x3 grid of the parts and ended up putting them on a raft - there isn't much cross sectional area so getting them to stick was not easy. I have a pretty thick shell set on my slicer (Cura) so they printed as solids (cross section of the part is 1.34mm).

The designs were done in Solidworks 2013.

Link to LED strip:
https://www.amazon.com/Razon-Lighting-Theater-Backlighting-increase/dp/B01GJFDN30/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1494102115&sr=8-1&keywords=B01GJFDN30

author: ass3nt3

description.text:
I created this to support the popular Samyang (Pro-Optic etc.) 8mm lens and use it to create spherical panoramas (AKA 360x180 or Equirectangular). I use a Nikon D7000 body, but this mount will accommodate other DSLR bodies. The head of the mount has detents to allow you to easily align the camera (in portrait mode) horizontally (for standard panoramas), -15 degrees and +60 degrees. To create a spherical image, take 6 photos (60 degrees apart) with the camera pointed at -15 degrees and two photos pointed at +60 degrees (180 degrees apart of course). Longer lenses will require more photos so do a little research if you're using something other than the Samyang 8mm lens. You can deal with the small gap under the tripod with photoshop or an image taken hand held (good luck with that). There are many tutorials on the web detailing the process to create the spherical image from these 8 (or 9) photos. I use the open source software Hugin, but there are other solutions.

For initial setup, measure the distance from the bottom of your camera to the center of the lens and secure the vertical arm so the center of the lens is in line with the center of the tripod mount. On the horizontal arm, where the camera is mounted, mount the camera so the lens nodal point is in line with the pivot point. For the Samyang lens, this seems to be at the gold ring that's near the end of the lens.

My printer bed is not big enough to print the vertical arm and the very small part that aligns the arm with the base so I split it off. The alignment pin is designed to be attached to the bottom part of the vertical arm with glue and a couple of small screws. I used 1/4-20 bolts and nuts to attach the vertical arm to the base, the vertical arm to the horizontal arm, and camera to the horizontal arm. I had on hand a knob with an embedded 1/4-20 threaded rod, but you could also use a bolt and wing nut.

As you can see from the photo, there is an inset for a common bubble level. The diameter of the level is 43mm. (example https://wholesaler.alibaba.com/product-detail/bubble-level-vials_60291126290.html)

See some of my panoramas at https://www.360cities.net/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&query=wt4y and https://www.flickr.com/photos/wt4y
Fusion 360
An elegant barley twist coat hook with the bust of my good friend Huertanix

title: Flower Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just in time for Mothers Day!!
This design like my others will either accommodate 3/4" X 3/16" button magnets or three pennies.
I like using magnets because you can use them to make each other spin, stick to fridge, etc.
To insert the weights just pause at the corresponding layer at the top of the magnets or pennies in each hole. "you don't have to add the weights but they will not spin as long"
I did not include spinner caps because there are already plenty of good designs.
The caps shown are Large Finger 608 Bearing Caps - by Wingnut2k.
Although I did have a hard time getting his caps to print well.
I may design some at a later time.
You can get the magnets at most craft stores, I picked up a 52 pack at Walmart for $6.

Tips:
Do not use supports otherwise your holes will get filled up.
Depending on your software use the option to not cross the outline for travel movements.
This keeps the holes free and clear of any strands of stray filament.
If you look at the pictures I paused right before layer 31 to get the magnets in place.
But this will change depending on what settings you use.

Scale to fit, it may or may not fit your particular bed.   
When finished, be very careful taking it off the print bed, with all the fine detail, its very easy to break. But, with care it can be taken off just fine.  
Have fun!

title: QAV-M 110 Micro Quad FT Gremlin Frame

description.text:
With the new micro quad scene emerging I have modeled a 110 version of the QAV210 frame to be used either with EMAX power pack micro system or your standard 1104 mount.

There is also a second top plate with more clearance for the larger emax 2345BN props

All you need are nylon stand offs for the vertical posts. The model uses M3 standoffs

https://www.amazon.com/180Pcs-M3-Hex-Spacers-Screw-Nut-Standoffs-Quadcopter-Drone-Raspberry/dp/B01I0SORIE/ref=sr_1_2?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1494106444&sr=1-2&keywords=m3

Lots of fun, hope you like it as much as I do.

https://youtu.be/Bl26f9nuWLA

For this build I used the EMAX micro brushless power pack system:

  • EMAX Femto F3 Flight Controller+PDB Board
  • 4x EMAX Bullet 6A BLHeli_S ESC (1S-2S Support)
  • 4x EMAX RS1104 5250kv Brushless Motors

  • EMAX T2345BN Props

  • Airblade TQ169 AiO VTX/Camera http://bit.ly/2r5lMsL
  • Frsky XM+ Receiver http://bit.ly/2r9kVSF

But then one of my motors died, so I swapped them to standard 1104 motors:

  • DYS BE1104 5400KV http://bit.ly/2s7eTY2
  • 2035 x4 Props http://amzn.to/2siyQdL

Printer:

xyz da vinci pro

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

30%

title: Spool holder for large filament spools

description.text:
This is a fairly simple spool holder for the large 300m spools with 3mm filament. The design is similar to many other holders, but this one was made using a CNC milled sandwich plate for the sides and M8 threaded rods to keep everything together.

If you don't have access to a CNC machine, the sides can also be printed in plastic or maybe lasercut in plywood or even acrylic.

Materials and methods

I have used sandwich plate for the two sides, but as mentioned, other materials can be used (eg. wood or plexiglass) or ABS and PLA when printing the two sides.

The bearings are regular skateboard/roller blade bearings so they should be available everywhere for pretty cheap (used bearings will probably work OK too).

title: Enclosure for the Rostock Max V2 3D-Printer

description.text: This is a documentation to build a DIY enclosure for the 3D printer model Rostock Max V2 (should also work for V3) that is part of the RepRap family of 3d printers and sold by SeeMeCNC and through various resellers. This project uses PLA and ABS prints with the printer itself, laser cut acrylic sheets and a few metric of-the-shelf components only. See here for full documentation and assembly instructions: https://docubricks.com/viewer.jsp?id=6526269302458755072 (https://docubricks.com/search.jsp). Enclosures are typically self-built, because a USA patent seems to be an obstacle for most providers to sell them as standard accessory. Enclosures are desirable to improve the quality of especially ABS prints by increasing the temperature of the print environment and by preventing quick temperature changes e.g. by drafts. ABS print especially benefit from both a lower temperature difference between the heated printer bed and the environment because the material shrinks more than PLA when cooling down, which leads to warping and splitting of prints. Please share if you implement further improvements for this enclosure.

title: Kossel Carriage, integrated belt clip and screw for endstop

description.text:
This is a carriage designed for my delta printer, which i am building at the moment.
Should be used togehter with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2301009

"V2":

  • The two holes for the M3 nuts are deeper. So i can use these parts:
    https://www.3dware.ch/Kugelgelenk--M3-auf-M3-6-Stk.-De.htm
  • The thing has a 20mm deep hole for M3 screws to adjust the endstop.
  • You can clip the GT2 belt together, like i did oder put the lose end in the slot whit the printed GT2 profile. The profile is theoretical exact the same like a GT2 belt.
  • The rounded section oposite of the GT2 profile is because i have some problems with layer adhesion. I think, it makes small details a bit stronger.

"V3":

  • Made the gap to insert the belt a bit smaller. You can no longer clip the belt together like before. But the construction should be more stable now.

Thanks for any feedback

description.text:
Es una trampa para que los bichos bolitas no se suban a los troncos donde están fructificando las Gírgolas (Pleurotus Ostreatus).
Con el agua del riego se llena el cuenco de las trampas y los bichos bolitas no pueden subir a comer los hongos.

Yo puse 3 por tronco, fijadas con tornillos autoperforantes de 2 pulgadas de largo.

Puede servir para cualquier otro caso donde se desee que no suban insectos.

Para imprimirlo hay que girarlo 180° (con la parte grande sobre la cama).

This is a mount for a LEI kite to mount a GoPro to the strut.  It is similar to thing:148001 but I wanted to bolt the camera directly to the mount rather than using the shoe.  This thing is currently untested.

I used a 3mm brim to get it to stay down on the bed.  I also ran it a little hotter than this particular filament likes to go at since this black stuff doesn't seem to bond as well as some of the others I've used.  
Use neoprene or a sponge or something similar between the mount and the strut.  The strap slot can be modified in the SCAD file if needed.  Be sure to use a leash on the camera!  It would be a good idea to leash the cam to the pump loop on the leading edge.  
I borrowed the actual mount bit from someone else's thing, but I was unable to located it to give it due credit.  It was a GoPro kit with many different style linkages.  If someone knows what I mean let me know and I'll add it.  Thanks.

title: Kite:  Slingshot style active stopper ball

description.text: This is a stopper ball which resembles the Slingshot brand unit but has larger line holes for older bars such as the lock n load. This is esentially "cruise control" for a kite. IF IT WORKS, it will alow the user to pull the ball down and set the sheeting so that arm muscle isn't needed to keep the kite parked. This piece is untested (I haven't even printed it yet). I don't know how well PLA will work for this, but please, do not try to use this if you are a novice, because if it fails, it could cause your safety equipment to fail. I will test it, and perhaps come up with other designs for this, but I will probably use nylon when I get that far (meaning when it gets warm enough). Update: I did print it and it came out quite nice. I'll take a picture next time I pull my bar out. It works--too well I might add. It does not self release. Once the bar is sheeted and the ball is pulled down it will not let go without pulling the bar in a smidge first and manually pushing the ball up the line. This makes it extremely difficult to quickly sheet out the bar to handle gusts.

author: FBinfantry

description.text:
THIS IS NOT MY OWN DESIGN! I am sharing the files from Richard Bowman documented in the public domain in detail here on DocuBricks: http://docubricks.com/viewer.jsp?id=9134926926759813120#brick_909106319 here on github: https://github.com/rwb27/openflexure_microscope, here published: http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4941068, and here on Waterscope: http://www.waterscope.org/.
Optomechanics is a crucial part of any microscope; when working at high magnification, it is absolutely crucial to keep the sample steady and to be able to bring it into focus precisely. Accurate motion control is extremely difficult using printed mechanical parts, as good linear motion typically equires tight tolerances and a smooth surface finish. This design for a 3D printed microscope stage uses plastic flexures, meaning its motion is free from friction and vibration. It achieves steps well below 100nm when driven with miniature stepper motors, and is stable to within a few microns over several days. This design aims to minimise both the amount of post-print assembly required, and the number of non-printed parts required - partly to make it as easy as possible to print, and partly to maximise stability; most of the microscope (including all the parts with flexures) prints as a single piece. The majority of the expense is in the Raspberry Pi and its camera module; the design requires only around 100g of plastic and a few nuts, bolts and other parts. The optics module (containing the camera and lens) can be easily swapped out or modified, for example to add epifluorescence or change the magnification.

I ran workshops based on the design, which is highly rewarding. A must try!

Assembly needed

No post-printing treatment is required except assembly: http://docubricks.com/viewer.jsp?id=9134926926759813120#bom

OpenSCAD parametric design

The design files can be found here: https://github.com/rwb27/openflexure_microscope

Water analysis DIY tool suitable for education This tool is part of the WaterScope initiative: http://www.waterscope.org/ and can be used for educational purposes for older students, for hobbyists, at University, for fieldwork and research.

biology, optics, microscopy, 3d printing This object can both be used to learn how to 3d-print, how to build a microscope, and to use the digital microscope, e.g. to study bacteria: http://www.waterscope.org/bacteria_testing-2/

description.text:
An upright stand I made for the Nyrius BR50 AptX Bluetooth receiver. It most likely works on the BR40 (the one without the AptX) and the BR51 (the one with the AptX and the NFC; no idea how it'll affect the NFC though). It might work with the BR41 and other bluetooth receivers of similar make as the BR50.

To make the feet, I simply cut discs from a 7mm black hot gluestick with an exacto knife - the holes at the bottom are 2mm deep, so you only need four little feet about 3mm each. Afterwards the Nyrius receiver should just slide in, and you're good to go.

I've also included a "No Feet" version, in case you don't want to bother doing the gluestick thing, or you want to resize the object to fit something larger or smaller (a Wi-Fi router, perhaps? A book?). For reference, the width of the "slot" is 2.0cm on the .stl, and fits a 1.95cm thick object (eg. the receiver) snugly.

This test is inspired by Maker's Muse test.

I found a similar test but it did not have pins for tool force.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6QhYpQ7TOjY

I tried to optimize the plastic usage/print time, but still make it possible to test for z-wobble imperfections etc.

My GeeeTech Prusa I3 managed to go down to 0.3mm clearance with a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layer height. The 0.1mm and 0.2mm were completely stuck.

Happy testing :-)

Let me know what you think about it.

Best regards
Søren

I have looked at your picture once more, I think that you are over extruding, the top text is also not easy readable.
Try to print the test with a lower extruder multiplier e.g. 0.95
The proper way is to do a filament calibration, see the following video: https://youtu.be/Kgy8hVKxtVs
Have you set your slicer to use the right nozzle size?

author: Alien2010

description.text:
Fidget Spinners can be cheap, i wanted to design my own simply, because I could. It was a fun process.
The caps provided the largest problem, finding the best dimensions for the grip,tolerance for 608 bearing and clearance of the bearing and underside of the cap.

Testing the dimensional accuracy and reliability of my printer regarding dimensions was easy enough, i took some advice from 3DPrintingNerd from youtube to have a tolerance of 0.05. This tolerance worked out great for me :)

Have fun Spinning and fidgeting but more importantly, printing :)
acetone dipping can be done to achieve a very smooth finish(may affect tolerances for holes)

This is another MPCNC cable chain for the Z axis electronics. The main difference is that it is connected to the XY carriage instead of being connected to the Z axis straight. This potentially will reduce the amount of torque applied to the Z axis from the chain itself.

The chains listed at thingiverse are either too small or too large for my taste. Besides I wanted to have it printed as links in place. The small one I saw I was unable to even break into pieces after printing. So I based the design on the large one:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1429885

It printed nicely. But was too big. The chain here was scaled down about 75%. With tolerance between links adjusted accordingly. As a test I printed 3 piece section. 6 and 9 section files are essentially the same.

The aluminum angle is 1 inch one. The angle mount file is for one only. Another one needs to be printed mirrored from the same file. The mounts are for NEMA 23 motors. SKP files are provided for convenience and modifications. For NEMA 17 steppers angle mounts need to be modified! I might add it later.

The chain is attached to the angle with a clamp. However the end link is designed so it can be secured by the #6 screws too.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40

description.text:
-¡ Hola a todos!

Hace varios meses nos mantuvimos a la espectativa de contar con nuestro propio vehículo omnidireccional. Así que basados en el archivo "Rueda Omnidireccional" que puedes encontar en nuestro perfil Thingiverse, les traemos a Shuk en su version Omni.

Entre los archivos podrás encontrar un sencillo esquema y diseño en PCB como imagen... si como imagen, dado que puedes encontar infinidad de circuitos para mismo fin (accionamiento de 3 motores DC de 5V). De no ser así, buscanos por redes sociales y te enviaremos los archivo en Cadsoft EAGLE además del código de control y una app con la que lo controlamos via Bluetooth.

Te dejamos un corto video de su funcionamiento... Y como siempre: cuestas con los archivos para que los modifiques, mejores y compartas.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cgfJObe0y38&feature=youtu.be&a

Si gustas síguenos por redes sociales.

¡No seas un simple mortal...!

title: Child Frames - Nonny Mask Adapted
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is pair of eyeglass frames that will attached to the Bridge of a Nonny Pediatric Nasal CPAP mask with headgear. It should be printed in Flexible Resin. I've done so via the Formlabs Form2 Durable Resin. As is, the frames will fit lenses cut for the MiraFlex Baby Plus 39/14, However, your optometrist should be able to cut lenses for them with an in-office trace. Also, the design could be adapted to mimic other frames and masks.

I recommend getting some tiny ponytail rubber bands or orthodontic rubber bands to help secure frame bridge to the mask's nose-bridge depth adjustment (visible in the photo). This takes 2seconds to place and will make it very easy to slide them on and off. This will also help to keep them from falling off during head-flips or from being knocked off by the bed the child is lying on.

Fortunately, the glasses don't come in contact with the individual. So, they really should not become uncomfortable. Sleeping with them one really shouldn't be uncomfortable.

I truly hope this helps more mask wearers to see the world!

Please understand that I am not an Optometrist, Opthamologist, nor do I have extensive training in vision or eyecare. Please consult your doctor before using these frames with corrective lenses.

description.text:
The Mecca of the Boy Scouts of America is Philmont Scout ranch, located in the beautiful Sangre de Cristo Mountains of northern New Mexico. It has achieved a cult-like following, and for good reason.

The Boy Scouts does a good job of teaching kids about orienteering, map reading etc - But something I never had as a kid was full 3d topo maps. If I had this kind of model as a kid, I know I would have spent more time engaged in orienteering classes, and less time rolling my eyes.

For all you scouts and scouters out there, I hope this brings back fond memories. I dunno about you, but I wanna go back to Philmont!

remixed_from.author: jjpowelly
remixed_from.title: The Universal Spool Holder - Main Page

description.text:
Note: I just quickly threw this together. Hopefully soon I'll have more time to test edit, and write about it.

Based loosely on the universal spool holder design by jjpowelly, but it is a complete redesign. I'm planning on setting up a pegboard next to my printer, and wanted to be able to mount my filament on there. There are other pegboard filament spool holders out there, but I wanted one that was simple and used minimum materials, printing with very few supports.

This is mainly designed for a hatchbox spool, but could be used for many other spools less than 3.5" wide, 9" Diameter, and with a central hole diameter greater that 1.9"

To hold multiple spools, the "center holder" file can also be used for further support. Remember you will have to add an additional 4" of pipe for every extra spool you hold (so two is 8" and 3 is 12".)

The only place supports are needed is on the actual pegs.

Materials

You'll need one of each side, as well as a 4" long piece of nominal 1.5" PVC pipe (actual OD is 1.9".) A replica of the pipe is also available if you'd rather print it in both 4" and 8" lengths.

Assembly

Put your spool on the pipe, then sandwich it between either side. Insert the upper curved hooks into your pegboard, then gently tilt to insert the bottom pegs.

Edit 5/27/2017

Updated needed pipe lengths to fit a new calculation that should be correct as well as the corresponding pipe files.

Edit 5/8/2017

Flipped file "right holder" 180 degrees for better printing.

author: docj452

description.text:
Air filter intake pipe.
This is a simple modification for the HPI RS4 3 Drift nitro car air intake. The factory fitted rubber pipe bend needs to be turned upside down and needs to face forward. A hole (size depends on air filter diameter) needs to be cut in the hood of the car body. I prefer to use the
k&n breather filter, but don't forget air filter oil! Ps.. This is my very first design :)

Front splitter.
I felt the front end of the car could do with a little more protection against curbs so I designed this splitter. It protects the nose of the car by absorbing most of the impacts through the foam bumper which it is mounted to. You'll need to cut the shell in the front to accommodate the splitter. It then simply fits at the bottom of the foam bumper using screws. It was printed using support set to everywhere.

Rear splitter and tail pipe.
The rear splitter was initially also made to help protect against bumps but I soon got tired of the oil that splashes all over the inside of the shell.The car still uses the factory exhaust and this part only replaces the aluminum pipe that was fitted to the exhaust. Once again you"ll have to cut the shell to accommodate this part. Support was set to "touching build plate".I printed it using carbon fiber pla and so far it hasn't melted :) *NOTE.. The exhaust pipe seems to break because of vibration. I"ll update this part as soon as I'm done with modifications to it.

Exhaust bracket.
This is a simple bracket I made to accommodate a side mounted exhaust pipe. The bracket worked fine but I wasn't happy with the performance of the pipe I used so I completely removed it from my car.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

title: Improved Compact Bowden Extruder, direct drive 1.75mm (6mm fittings)

description.text:
Schlotzz's compact bowden extruder modified & reinforced to take 6mm threaded push fittings (rather than typical 5mm). Provides a more robust connection without need for threaded inserts.

Push fitting holes have been extended to allow for tapping (recommended).

Idler adjusted to apply more pressure / work with undersized filaments and to allow easier release.

Supports:

No

Infill:

30% triangle

Notes:

To prevent ABS warping print using a 6mm+ brim.

Clean up holes with a small drill bit or file.
SLOWLY Tap the push fit holes with a 6mm tap. You may be able to screw straight into the plastic but it's not advised.

print_settings.Notes:: Print a test male/female roller before a batch so that you can adjust your settings accordingly, I have found that a higher layer height makes their fit too loose and a shorter layer height much tighter. I used a vice-grip to push the rollers together if that gives you an idea of the force needed for the best fit.

description.text:
This is a mecanum wheel that doesn't require any hardware to assemble and is compatible with those classic yellow gearboxes from China.

The only thing required is electrical tape (or similar) to wrap the rollers with to give them friction, and maybe a drill to ensure the holes for the rollers are large enough (they shrink if the print warps)

The rollers press-fit together quite tightly and will not fall apart unless they are printed incorrectly.

ps. to get the opposite side for the wheel hub, you can invert it in most slicers.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Notes:

These can be tricky to print, I would recommend a large brim for the wheel, you do not want any warping (else you will have to clean up the holes in the hub with a drill).

The rollers should be printed in a lower layer height and also require a brim. I would print the rollers with a layer height of 0.2mm or less (and I'm using a 0.4mm nozzle)

Print a test male/female roller before a batch so that you can adjust your settings accordingly, I have found that a higher layer height makes their fit too loose and a shorter layer height much tighter. I used a vice-grip to push the rollers together if that gives you an idea of the force needed for the best fit.

description.text:
Case for a DIY Nintendo Advantage style controller for use with the NES Classic Edition (aka the Nintendo Mini).

I'm still new to FreeCAD so hopefully the FCStd file will make sense for those that want to change it to fit your choice of joystick and button manufacturers or resize the mounts for metric screws. The mounts are sized to be tapped for 4-40 screws.

I used an Atmega328P-PU microcontroller to emulate a Wii Classic Controller but without the X/Y/L/R buttons and analog sticks. You could use the controller for the Wii but for only 2 button games. If you want to flash your own chip, the source code is in on GitHub, NesClassicAdvantage. I have a demo of the controller still on breadboard at https://youtu.be/zpsMyRHSjoE.

Demo in the printed case: https://youtu.be/YNn1uIbvmds

Instructable at http://www.instructables.com/id/DIY-NES-Classic-Advantage-Controller/

Thank you for looking.

After completing my first fish puzzle (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227995) my students looked at it and were unimpressed. They told me that I could do better, and I agreed. So the next day I visited my wife's classroom and she had a goldfish sitting on her desk that looked to be made out of pieces of cardboard. I took some pictures of it and then went home and tried to create something similar. After almost two whole days of design as well as several failed printing attempts, I believe I came up with a pretty good result. This goldfish looks great sitting on a bookshelf and can also be hung up by a string through the hole in its top fin. I was also inspired by HeavyRoation's 3D puzzles which include this design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:99250) and is also one of my favorite things that I 3D printed.

Print out all parts. No supports or rafts needed.  
For construction help see: 3D Puzzle Goldfish Construction Manual.pdf

I added a zip folder to make downloading all of the STL files easier. I also added a more detailed construction manual to help when putting this fish together. It labels the parts by number and has arrows to show where the parts need to go. Hope this helps!

title: Front Suspension Fork Lockout Cable Guide

description.text:
This is an expansion-based plug that fits in the bottom of your 1-1/8" STRAIGHT steerer (not tapered; I don't own a tapered steerer fork, so I don't know the dimensions). It provides a cable GUIDE (not a stop) to route shift cable housing on its way from the handlebar remote to the lockout switch.

I will be uploading a switch/cap & crown-mounted cable stop separately.

6 May 17: I have no idea if this works yet. Print at your own risk. I'll test it to see if it fits at some point.

I was inspired by AlsHub's part on Shapeways: https://www.shapeways.com/product/D4HB2EJNT/lockout-1-1-8

Plus this thread: http://forums.mtbr.com/shocks-suspension/remote-lockout-fox-rl-382180-6.html

I wanted to make a cleaner version that wouldn't require drilling through your existing switch.

The inner diameter of a 1-1/8" steerer is 1", based on my research.

13 May 17: I didn't even check my steerer, which is actually 20.95 mm ID. So a new version has been uploaded, with 20.95 appended to the file name.

You'll need a M6 x 35 mm bolt. It needs to be at least 35 mm long, if not longer.

You'll need an M6 nut too.

Insert the nut into the plug, & make sure to insert this into the spines correctly. There's a slight draft angle that's used to expand the spines outward to fit into your steerer.

Insert the assembly into your steerer, & tighten the bolt.

comments.author: AndyJ288

description.text: Allows you to level your dual nozzles on replicator

After disassembling my extrustion heads after a clog, I found that restoring the nozzles to the same height is next to impossible. Makerbot industries said the only way to level them is to return the assembly to them..Well I don't own anyting I can't fix. Where will I be if I am in a middle of a critical job!!
The main issue stems from the fact that the extruder bar is threaded where it accepts the nozzle(part #MP2590 if you have downloaded replicator part files). As well as having a nut at the top and bottom of the nozzle...This many threaded parts makes getting the level and orentation right next to impossible....I beleive that the top and bottom nuts will work as jam nuts and fix the extruder nozzle in place, if tightened properly, making the threaded bar redundant.
To fix this I machined a new mounting bar (MP 2590) with the holes NOT threaded (I used a 6 mm hole this left a little slop you might try smaller to get better alignment). You may just drill out you existing mounting bar (careful a replacment might be hard to get), I wanted to presserve mine in case I had to go back for some reason.
I still needed a reference to level the nozzles on my new mounting bar. I designed this simple fixture that allowed me to get them within .001 inch.
You simply adjust the top and bottom nuts until you get the nozzles level (use feeler guages to measure the gap between the nozzle and fixture). Make sure you really tighten the nuts against each other such that they do not losen.
You will have to recalibrate the nozzles offset. The calibration routine on your replicator should allow for this.
The only risk I see with this change is that the nuts ?may? loosen over many heat cycles, if the nuts are tightened enough this should not happen. So far I have not had a problem with this.

comments.text: I've installed new nozzles on my FFCP and so this jig is a bit too short. Would you mind uploading the original cad file I can edit it in solidworks please?
comments.author: Ansonwing

comments.text: Your jig saved me a lot of grief.  The process is a PITA, but without your jig, it would have been virtually impossible.  Thanks!
comments.author: bottleworks

comments.text: thanks for showing how it is done on a makerbot, that will make it easier to make it work on an Ultimaker too.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: We (Ultimaker users with experimental Dual head) are also working out on how to get the nozzles level.
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Easiest way is to use a unified heaterblock. Drill some holes between the sections or a full channel to minimize the thermal transfer between sections. No more alignment problems. (Assuming the nozzles are the same height once tightened in).
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: what if your heateblock is not level? So that solves no problem, and you lose thermal isolation between the two.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Leveling a unified heaterblock is no different than leveling the entire hot end dualstrsion unit. And the majority of thermal isolation can be maintained by removing most of the material between the two. The biggest gain is a guaranteed uniformity of distance from the nozzle end to the heater block. If the nozzle holes are straight and the nozzles are uniform then there is zero calibration work to even up the nozzle heights. Leveling the heaterblock is simpler than two adjustable, independent heater blocks and can be managed via a single thumbscrew.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: Theoreticallly yeah, howeverI have found that when dealing with mass manufacturing and precise alignment must be made (especially with threaded part heights) it is best to have some way to adjust for manufacturing tolerances. If you do not build this into the design and plan on perfect manufacturering you with have issues (and high expences)
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I should add that by no means do I think the thing on this page is anything less than awesome. Just throwing my $.02 in on another possilble way to address the leveling issue.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Indeed, Jelle raises a valid point.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

title: keurig Hack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Keurig hack. inspired by the keurig freedom key.

you can cut out the rim of original Keruig cup and glue/tape it to by pass the DRM check.
you can tape a purple post it note on other side to unlock the hidden menu (Vue Cup menu) if you want to make bigger size brews, etc.
you'll have to find the right color of post it note for this to work.

Note that if you print with PLA it might be soften by the heat. recommend to use ABS for this.

author: Tysongraphics

title: Print-In-Place Fidget Cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: An updated model of the Fidget Cube is contained in the new Fidget Star. A print-in-place folding fidget cube, with customization options for size, shape, and clearances. As you fold the cube it turns inside out to form another cube! Makes a nice gift or 3D-printing demo, and is fun to fidget with while on the bus, standing in line, etc. This model prints in ONE PIECE (!), fully assembled, without raft and without supports, and then you snap it open in a couple of places until it moves freely; see the instructions. Customize size and tolerances for you printer with the Customizer link! For a video illustrating how this type of cube folds and moves, see emmett's great separate-pieces design at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:135836, which was the inspiration for this model. For the smallest possible working fidget cube with clearances optimized for MakerBot printers, use the "fidgetcube48.stl" file. For more information about how this model was made, see MakerHome Day 145, Day 146,
Day 147, and Day 148. =====

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

Print with no raft and no supports in the vertical position. Each file corresponds to one of the colors of models in the picture; they differ only by size of model and size of hinges. One additional model, the "fidgetcube48", is a very small fidget cube that is optimized for .2mm/Standard on a Replicator 2. After printing, carefully snap to free the vertical center hinges.
Then fold together vertically and carefully snap free the horizontal center hinges. If this doesn't seem possible then fold together vertically the other way and try again. Finally, snap free the horizontal hinges near the top and bottom. Again, if this doesn't seem possible then change the vertical configuration first.
Don't have a 3D printer, or want something fancy printed for you? We don't have Fidget Cubes in our print-to-order store yet, but we have other cool stuff you can check out:

comments.text: I'm sure you already solved this, but if you are printing into the air, it's actually probably because your build plate is too low, and your first layer is not adhering. Be sure you are level, and move it up by fractions of a millimeter uniformly, if you can figure out a way to do that. This problem can occur on some prints and not others because your first layer might be thinner, and thus it is more sensitive to a lower bed.  If your first layer is thinner than the space between the extruder and the print bed, the print won't stick.
comments.author: krumerya23

comments.text: Hi krumerya23, if your printer is air-printing, maybe you are having an extrusion problem or a clog?  Usually an air-print is due to a problem happening with the printer, not the model.  If you're having trouble with only this one model, but other models print fine, then maybe try re-downloading this model again, or re-making it in Customizer if that's how you made it the first time.

I had to experiment a lot until I found the right clearance for my machine. If you find something that works, please reply so that other with your machine can try the same settings.

comments.text: Sometimes I have a problem with the outside of the horizontal hinges. Because they print without support, a little bit of material droops under the outside of the hinge. Then when you try to snap the hinge, the droopy pieces get in the way. Try this: before trying to break the hinges, keep the cube oriented the way it was when it printed and then use some snippers to remove any droopy bits that are under the outside of the horizontal hinges. Let me know if that helps!

comments.author: kuhnpd11

comments.text: The remeshed was put through a couple of filters in MeshLab to remove some non-manifold faces and/or edges. For some reason MakerWare didn't have a problem with them, but Slic3r did. So if you use Slic3r then use the remeshed. The problem seems to lie with direct OpenSCAD output, which is what my sample files are. If you make your own new files with the Thingiverse Customizer then they will not require remeshing.
comments.author: kuhnpd11

comments.text: I found that on my Replicator 2x, taking the acrylic dome off helped to allow for faster cooling. Nice design by the way! Nice giveaways! Would it be alright to sell these?

comments.text: I am wondering why you decided to go with the tapered pin hinges rather than just using through pins, since it is printed in one part anyways.  I have been having trouble with printing this, as slicer seems to have an issue with the top central hinge, even after running it through netfabb.  I would have thought simple through pins would be simpler and might even print better.
comments.author: pyrophreek

comments.text: hi pyrophreek, I tried through-pin hinges in a previous design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:144645)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... but the hinges weren't as reliable as I wanted. with these cone hinges, they sides of the hinges never touch when printing (except when printed vertically), and there is nothing to break or bridge inside the hinge. this makes the hinges really strong even when they are really small.

comments.text: What would you suggest for the infill, shells, temperature, and File to download? I am unable to get the cube to work, the hinges always break after I take it off :(
comments.author: lsvoichick

comments.text: The default clearances work well on a Replicator 2 with MakerWare .2mm/Standard with no rafts and no support. That's .2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill, but on a different printer things might work a little differently. For me when the hinges broke off during testing, it was either because the stacking_clearance was too low (and thus too much force was required to snap open the model), or way more likely, because the hinge_clearance was too low (and thus the hinge ended up being stuck together or glued to the adjacent cube).  So I recommend using the Customizer to increase your hinge clearance. Then print one and a half levels of cubes and test from there. If you get it to work please leave a note here with your printer and the settings/clearances you used so that other people with your machine can get it working too.
comments.author: lsvoichick

comments.text: Thanks mathgrrl! I'm going to give this a try tonight. I've printed eight of the "stock" versions on my Replicator 2 using the settings suggested, but the horizontal hinges always break. I'm hopeful the customized version will take care of the problem because I love this Thing you've created!
comments.author: mathgrrl

comments.text: Shot in the dark here, but... any chance you are using supports? I know it seems impossible but this model is built to print with NO supports and no raft. If you were using supports it would glue the hinges together and they would break.  Since you have a Rep2 like me, I'm thinking the same settings should work... ? Please keep me posted, I'd love to know what makes it work for you. (Also, sometimes I have had better luck with translucent filament than opaque filament, and all the filament I have used for this project has been from MakerBot. Not sure if that makes a difference but it might, in the clearances?)
comments.author: JONeillSr

comments.text: JONeillSr - here is an update that might help you.  I just tried the smallest default model (the white one) with an opaque MakerBot filament and it broke (although for me it was the vertical hinges). This model had printed fine with translucent filament previously. So I tried again but increased the hinge_clearance to .5 and it worked perfectly! I hope that works for you too.
